speaker: Frasier
text: So just remember, when you're standing there, that what you're going through...

speaker: Kenny
text: Why hasn't Frasier mentioned the Spokane thing yet?

speaker: Roz
text: I don't know.  I'm sure we'll get to it by the end of the show.

speaker: Kenny
text: Well, he'd better, because I left him a memo and an email specifically asking him to promote the Spokane thing.  Now ignoring an email is one thing, but a memo and an email? Well, I may have to bring the hammer down and leave a Post-It on his desk.

speaker: Frasier
text: Which brings me to a bit of news.  Starting Monday, there will be a new addition to the Frasier Crane radio family: the city of Spokane.  [_smiles at Kenny_]

speaker: Kenny
text: Oh, thank goodness.  Man, that was like the Cuban Missile Crisis for a moment, wasn't it?

speaker: Frasier
text: In fact, KQZY is not only going to be carrying the show, but they've invited Roz and me to conduct Monday's broadcast from their studios in Spokane.  But fret not, Seattle.  Although my body will be 300 miles away, my heart will be firmly lodged in your radios. [_beat_] You know, that sounded a lot better this morning in the shower.  Anyway, good day and good mental health.

speaker: Roz
text: I thought Friday was your bath day.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah, I woke up late.  So, Roz, what time do you want me to pick up you and Roger on Sunday?

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, there's been a change in plans.  Roger is not coming to Spokane.

speaker: Frasier
text: Really?  Well, nothing wrong, I hope.

speaker: Roz
text: We broke up.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Roz, I'm so sorry.

speaker: Roz
text: We just talked about some problems we'd been having and decided, you know, we'd be better off apart.

speaker: Frasier
text: When did this happen.

speaker: Roz
text: Last week.

speaker: Frasier
text: Last week-?

speaker: Roz
text: I didn't tell you because I didn't want to have a long conversation.

speaker: Frasier
text: I understand.  You must be going through a lot right now. You know, back in private practice I used to tell my grief group...

speaker: Roz
text: See, this is exactly what I mean.  I appreciate your concern, but I am fine, really.

speaker: Frasier
text: Okay.  Boy, what a surprise.  No more Roger.

speaker: Roz
text: I know.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, he had a rare kind of dignity and integrity you don't see much of nowadays.  Especially among people who own a bench press.  You know, I don't believe I've ever met anyone else with that combination of gentility and brute strength. Well, not anybody single, anyhow.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm not helping, am I?

speaker: Roz
text: No.  _She goes into her booth.  FADE OUT  Scene Two - Apartment Frasier comes home from work and sees Niles at the bar pouring sherry._

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles!

speaker: Niles
text: Hey.

speaker: Frasier
text: I thought you and Daphne were going out tonight.

speaker: Niles
text: She's still getting ready.  Hey, Frasier, am I dressed appropriately for something called "Banana-rama"? [_he says wearing his traditional suit_]

speaker: Frasier
text: You're in Armani, who could object?

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, guys.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad.  _Martin is followed through the door by two workmen carrying a long, flat piece of lumber._

speaker: Martin
text: Uh, just lean it up against the window there, will you? [_they do_]

speaker: Frasier
text: What is this?

speaker: Martin
text: It's mahogany.  Real straight grain, too.  I found it outside the construction site next door?  Can you believe they were going to throw it away?

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, I thought we had this discussion when you found that mattress on the side of the highway.

speaker: Martin
text: But this isn't for resale, I'm going to make a TV table out of it.  [_tips the workmen as they leave_] Thanks, fellas.  Isn't it a beaut?

speaker: Niles
text: [_inspecting the underside_] There's a ketchup packet stuck to it.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, it's going to feel good to break out the tools, roll up my sleeves, and make something with my own two hands.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, are you sure this is a good idea?  Woodworking has never been your strength.

speaker: Niles
text: Yeah, I think the scariest words of my childhood were, "Your father needs your help down in the basement."

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I must have done something right.  I made a lot of good stuff.

speaker: Frasier
text: Even with directions, you could never assemble anything. I remember a play set where the slide ended right in front of the swings.

speaker: Niles
text: I don't remember that.

speaker: Frasier
text: I know.  Sorry.

speaker: Martin
text: Now, I'm gonna build a TV table, and I need a number one helper. Whose turn is it?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, I'm sorry, I'm sorry.  I am leaving for Spokane on Sunday, I will not be available.

speaker: Niles
text: Your show's not till Monday!

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well I have sponsors to meet, I have press interviews and photo sessions.  Niles, this is a very big step in my career. If I can prove that my brand of radio travels well, perhaps I can parlay Spokane into Denver, Chicago...  maybe even New York City.

speaker: Martin
text: [_to Niles_] Well, you win, buddy.  I'll see you tomorrow. Be sure to wear some work gloves.  Oh, and some coveralls. We don't want a repeat of that necktie-in-the-band-saw incident.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, great.  With my luck, there'll be a baseball game on the radio, too.

speaker: Frasier
text: It won't be so bad.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, how can you say that?  You once tried to report him to the Child Labor Board.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, at least I was being proactive.  I recall you used to lock yourself in the bathroom to cry.

speaker: Niles
text: I didn't go in there to cry.  I went in to re-gather my patience.

speaker: Frasier
text: Say, Niles, why don't you just ask Daphne to fill in for you?

speaker: Niles
text: Daphne?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, why not?  She's gonna owe you big time after dragging you to this banana event.

speaker: Niles
text: No, no, it's a concert.  And I hardly think it compares to the torture of assisting Dad. _Daphne comes out.  To borrow a phrase from Joe Keenan, "I lack the sartorial vocabulary to describe the result." I have an intimation that it's a fasion of the 70's.  Her hair is done up with an oversized silver bow, she's wearing a pink blouse with an oversized silver belt and a white jacket, and black pants with high white boots._

speaker: Daphne
text: All right, I'm ready.  [_sees him_] Oh, Niles, you're not going in those clothes.  Come with me.  [_takes his hand_] I got you some hair gel and parachute pants.  _As he is led to her room, Niles throws a frightened glance at Frasier.  FADE TO:_ **GETTING SULLIED** _Scene Three - KQZY Meeting Room Frasier stands by a podium while the station manager, Herm Evans, prepares him._

speaker: Herm
text: Okay, here's the drill.  Now, I'll introduce you to the reporters, they'll ask you questions.  Try not to go on too much.  The faster we get them to the courtesy liquor, the better.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, don't worry.  I'll be able to get my message across. You see, I'm a bit of a puppeteer when it comes to the press.

speaker: Herm
text: Good.  [_walks away, but turns back_] But still, liquor.

speaker: Kenny
text: Oh, sorry I'm late, Doc.  I, uh, had a situation at the hotel but it's under control now.

speaker: Frasier
text: Judging from the pillow wrinkles on your cheek, I'd say it was a nap situation.

speaker: Kenny
text: The point is, it's under control.

speaker: Herm
text: Kenny Daly!  Don't say hi or anything?

speaker: Kenny
text: Herm Evans! [_shakes his hand_] So, how's our star doing? Everything go okay with the CPS's?

speaker: Herm
text: Terrific.

speaker: Kenny
text: And your ExecComm?

speaker: Herm
text: Oh, they're thrilled.

speaker: Kenny
text: What about the M-and-M's?

speaker: Herm
text: [_hands him a bowl_] Help yourself.

speaker: Kenny
text: Thanks.

speaker: Roz
text: Hey, everybody.  [_they all greet her_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh listen, let me introduce you to Herm Evans, the station manager here.

speaker: Herm
text: [_shakes her hand_] Nice to meet you, Roz.

speaker: Roz
text: Thanks.

speaker: Herm
text: Now that everybody's here, I'll go get the reporters.

speaker: Frasier
text: Right, right.  [_Herm leaves_] Uh, Roz, listen.  Sure you're up to this?

speaker: Roz
text: Yeah, why?  Why wouldn't I be?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, it's been a tough time lately, you know, with the Roger situation.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, knock it off, Frasier.  I'm fine.

speaker: Frasier
text: You sure?

speaker: Roz
text: Yes.

speaker: Frasier
text: Because, believe me, I wouldn't blame you if you were struggling a little bit.  I mean, believe me, my head would be filled with "what if's" and "if only's" and, God forbid, the looming question, "What if I'll never again have the chance..." Oh, here comes the press!  All right, big smiles!  _Frasier takes the podium, having thrown Roz back into turmoil, as Herm leads in half a dozen reporters._

speaker: Herm
text: Thanks for coming, everybody! [_to a heavyset photographer_] Hey, Matt, is that a new tie, or did you just have it cleaned? [_laughs_] Hey, there'll be plenty of time for that cheese plate after you've fallen in love with KQZY's proud new addition, Dr. Frasier Crane.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you, thank you very much.  I'd like to take this opportunity to introduce my lovely producing partner, Roz Doyle.  [_puts his arm around her_] I must say, I'm looking forward to becoming part of the radio landscape here in Spokane.

speaker: Frank
text: [_male reporter_] Dr. Crane, how do you feel about taking over Neal Sullivan's time slot?

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm sorry, who?

speaker: Herm
text: Nobody, it's just the guy you're replacing.

speaker: Cathy
text: [_female reporter_] A nobody?  He's been a Spokane institution for 30 years.

speaker: Herm
text: Yes, we all saw your column.  You know what would make another great column?  Dr. Crane went to Harvard and Oxford.  Wow.

speaker: Frank
text: No offense, Dr. Crane, but all your degrees aren't going to make us forget about Sully.

speaker: Frasier
text: And I don't intend that they should.  I don't want you to forget about anyone.  I'm here to help people.

speaker: Cathy
text: Sully helps people.  Every Fourth of July, he organizes a group of troubled teens and cleans up all the trash on the riverbanks.

speaker: Frank
text: Will we be seeing you on the Fourth of July?

speaker: Herm
text: [_turns to the table_] Oh hey, what's this over here?  Free liquor?

speaker: Frank
text: Hey, Sully! [_all the reporters greet him_]

speaker: Sully
text: Hey, guys.  Don't let me interrupt.  I'm just clearing out a few things from my desk.  Wanted to stop by and wish my successor luck.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, thank you.  Thank you so much, Mr.  Sullivan.  And as someone who has served Spokane so well, your blessing is deeply appreciated.

speaker: Sully
text: Oh, you don't need my blessing.  I'm just a simple man with a passion for Spokane in his heart, and a termination notice in his pocket.

speaker: Cathy
text: Sully, will you be listening to Dr.  Crane's show tomorrow?

speaker: Sully
text: Not sure, Cathy.  I've been going around on that one like the horses on the Looff.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm sorry, the Looff?

speaker: Sully
text: It's a carousel.  But I guess you have to be in the city more than three hours to know that.

speaker: Frank
text: Sully, what are you going to do with your time now?

speaker: Sully
text: Good question, Frank.  When my dad retired, he died a month later.  Take that any way you like.  But, uh...  you know what, fellas, you really should be asking Dr. Crane the questions. Anyone needs me, I'll be down the street at Mulligan's, buying rounds.  Keep smiling.

speaker: Cathy
text: We'll miss you!  Let's hear it for Sully.

speaker: Press
text: [_singing_] For he's a jolly good fellow...  _As they continue, Frasier dismounts the podium, and motions to Kenny for a stiff drink.  Kenny, who has already poured one, hands it to Frasier and then takes a long pull straight from the bottle.  END OF ACT ONE  ACT TWO  Scene Four - Apartment Daphne and Martin, wearing work clothes and safety goggles, are standing over a piece of wood on a worktable._

speaker: Daphne
text: Now, I think we're going to need a smaller drill bit. Where's the chuck key?

speaker: Martin
text: The what?

speaker: Daphne
text: You know, [_points behind him_] that thing there.

speaker: Martin
text: [_holds it up, condescending_] The tighten-er.

speaker: Daphne
text: It's called the chuck key.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, maybe in England.  Here in the U.S., it doesn't have a specific name.

speaker: Daphne
text: Did you get the wood screws?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, damn!  I forgot to pick them up at the hardware store.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, don't worry, I'll run out and fetch them.

speaker: Martin
text: [_getting his coat_] No, it's all right.  I'll get them. Why don't you get started on the foot pads?

speaker: Daphne
text: All right. [_points_] Watch out for the extension cord. [_he stops_] That's the orange electricity hose.

speaker: Martin
text: I know what it is.

speaker: Niles
text: Hey, Dad.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, Niles.  I thought you were busy with an emergency at Northwest.

speaker: Niles
text: I-I was.  Actually, I just finished. [_points to his lapel_] See, this is my guest badge, that has today's date on it? You can't fake that.

speaker: Martin
text: Uh-huh.  See you in a half-hour. [_leaves_]

speaker: Niles
text: All right. [_to Daphne_] You look adorable. [_kisses her_] You look like the princess of safety.  Look, I'm so sorry for roping you into this.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, don't be.  Reminds me of when I used to mess about in the garage with my brothers.  Used to build all sorts of things. Splints, crutches, peg legs.

speaker: Niles
text: Still, you're very sweet to help Dad out.  I don't think I could take his bossiness.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, he's not so bad.  Could you hand me a rag?

speaker: Niles
text: [_looks_] Uh... sure. [_does_] Any interest in sneaking off to your room while the foreman's away?

speaker: Daphne
text: That sounds lovely, but first I have to get these pads on. Can you press on this for a moment?

speaker: Niles
text: Yeah, no problem. [_does_] Maybe later we'll try out my "Wagner for Lovers" CD.

speaker: Daphne
text: I need another rag.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, coming up... a rag. [_grabs one while keeping one hand on the pad_]

speaker: Daphne
text: Could you grab me some sandpaper, too?

speaker: Niles
text: [_fumbling_] Uh, yeah, sure.  Of course.

speaker: Daphne
text: Don't press too tight or the pad will slide.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh.

speaker: Daphne
text: Careful, even pressure. [_fixes his hand_] Like this.

speaker: Niles
text: Yeah, that's-that's what I'm doing.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, then why is glue squirting out?  I need the rag.

speaker: Niles
text: Okay. [_hands it to her_] Never said I was good at carpentry.

speaker: Daphne
text: Carpentry?  This is gluing felt.  Can you hand me the square?

speaker: Niles
text: Ah, yes. [_does_] Here's the square.

speaker: Daphne
text: No, no, no, [_points_] that one.  Why is the pad hanging off the side?

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I think that it slipped when I was handing you the rags and the sandpaper and the square, and by the way, you're welcome.

speaker: Daphne
text: By the way, still waiting for that sandpaper.

speaker: Niles
text: [_straightens up_] Okay, let's stop.

speaker: Niles
text: This is as bad as working with Dad.

speaker: Daphne
text: Look, Niles, I didn't mean to hurt your feelings.  I'm just trying to get this done and get it done well.  Okay?

speaker: Niles
text: Okay.

speaker: Daphne
text: I love you.

speaker: Niles
text: I love you, too.

speaker: Daphne
text: And yet, I'm still waiting for that sandpaper.  _FADE TO:  Scene Five - KQZY Studio Frasier surveys the radio booth while Roz is trying to get comfortable at her console.  Unlike KACL, this studio has no divide between the talent and producer's desks._

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, this layout doesn't really allow us to do any call screening.  Well, I guess you can still just check the sound levels.

speaker: Roz
text: Oh boy, the sound levels?  "Dear Diary, after years and years of wishing..."

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, all right, Roz.

speaker: Kenny
text: Hey, Doc.  Everything all right here?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yeah, it's fine.

speaker: Roz
text: But guess who gets to check the sound levels?

speaker: Frasier
text: I said all right, Roz.

speaker: Kenny
text: Just wanted to make sure you're relaxed and ready to go... and haven't read today's paper.

speaker: Frasier
text: I read it.  Everything from the adoring salute to Sully, to the cartoon of me and Satan doing a jig on Sully's coffin.

speaker: Herm
text: About that - it might be a good idea to steer clear of any on-air references to Sully.

speaker: Frasier
text: On the contrary, I intend to confront this situation head-on. I intend to reach out to the listeners, ease their suffering, and thereby demonstrate what we do best.

speaker: Herm
text: Now, that's the kind of attitude this station needs.  Of course, if your ratings are low, I still have to fire you. [_laughs_] What a crazy business, huh?

speaker: Roz
text: Ten seconds.

speaker: Kenny
text: Knock 'em dead.

speaker: Roz
text: [_whispering_] Good luck. [_points_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, and welcome from Seattle to Spokane, this is the Frasier Crane Radio Network.  We are broadcasting today from the Lilac City where we have just replaced a beloved local icon, Neal Sullivan.  Now, Sully did a lot for this city and in my own way I hope to make the same kind of contribution that he did.  With that in mind, let's go to the phones.  _He looks at Roz, who points back at him.  He looks at his own board, and presses a button._

speaker: Frasier
text: Go ahead, caller.  I'm listening.

speaker: Caller 1
text: [_v.o._] Go back to Seattle. [_hangs up_]

speaker: Roz
text: How was the level on that?

speaker: Frasier
text: Now, now, people, I understand how you might be angry, and there's nothing wrong with venting that feeling, but please stay on the line long enough for me to respond. [_presses another button_] Go ahead, I'm listening.

speaker: Caller 2
text: [_v.o._] Hi, I'm just letting all the Sully fans know we're boycotting KQZY until he comes back.

speaker: Frasier
text: Now people, please, we need to talk.  We need to move forward. Otherwise, we're just going to be going around and around like the horses on the Looff!

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, well, you know, perhaps our callers from Seattle could help show the new folds how it's done. [_looks at his alternate board_] I'm afraid we don't have any calls from Seattle.  This is strange.  Um...  perhaps this would be a good time to go to a commercial break here on the Frasier Crane Radio Network.

speaker: Kenny
text: Hey-hey, you're doing great.

speaker: Frasier
text: I am not, they hate me.

speaker: Kenny
text: Okay, since we're being straight... um, Herm doesn't think it's going very well.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well, where's my support?  Where are the callers from Seattle?

speaker: Kenny
text: Seattle isn't getting the signal. [_looks at Herm_]

speaker: Herm
text: Well, something's obviously screwed up at KACL.

speaker: Kenny
text: Oh, it's not KACL.  It's probably that transmitter you bought off the Ukrainian Internet. [_exits_]

speaker: Herm
text: [_follows him out_] Hey, 20 minutes ago you were really impressed with that Ukrainian Internet.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm sure the people of Spokane would just get on board if they could get some understanding of what we actually do. We could use a...  like an example.  You know, a sample call. [_looks at Roz_]

speaker: Roz
text: Are you asking me to call in?

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, please?  I tell you what - just make up something, anything at all.

speaker: Roz
text: Okay.  Five seconds.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, and welcome back to the Frasier Crane Show.  We are broadcasting today from KQZY in beautiful Spokane. [_Roz holds up four fingers_] Let's go to the phones. [_presses line four_] Hello, caller.  I'm listening.

speaker: Roz
text: Hi, Dr.  Crane.  My name is Ro... berta, and, um... I'm afraid of the dark.

speaker: Frasier
text: What is it about the dark that frightens you?

speaker: Roz
text: Um... I don't know.  Um...

speaker: Frasier
text: Often a fear of darkness is a fear of the unknown.  It is in darkness where our imaginations give shape to our deepest anxieties.  What image comes to mind for you?

speaker: Roz
text: Nothing, actually.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_eyes furious_] Nothing?

speaker: Roz
text: Yeah, when everything disappears, there's nothing.  Just emptiness.

speaker: Frasier
text: I see.  And what is it about the emptiness that frightens you?

speaker: Roz
text: It's... lonely, for one thing.

speaker: Frasier
text: Have you always felt this way?

speaker: Roz
text: For a while I didn't.

speaker: Frasier
text: What was different then?

speaker: Roz
text: I had somebody.  A guy I really liked.  And then we broke up... [_breaks down crying_] Oh God, Frasier.  I miss him so much. I-I don't know how I fell in love again.  I mean, I swore I wouldn't.  I knew better.  I _should_ have known better!  And then, sure enough, six months in, he tells me there's no fireworks.  And what am I supposed to say? [_sobs_]

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm so sorry.  But listen to me.  You can't blame yourself for letting someone into your heart.  Love is always a risk.  But you have to take it.  The pain you're feeling now will pass in time, and you'll find yourself ready to take that risk again.  Until then... take comfort in your friends.  They want to help you.  They love you.

speaker: Roz
text: Yeah, thanks.

speaker: Frasier
text: You're welcome.  _They throw off their headphones, get up and embrace.  Kenny rushes in, pointing urgently at the lit-up "ON THE AIR" sign. They break apart and resume their positions._

speaker: Frasier
text: Okay, Spokane.  Let's hear what you have to say. [_presses button_] Go ahead, caller.  I'm listening.

speaker: Caller 3
text: [_v.o._] Hi, Dr.  Crane.  I was going to say "you suck" but while the phone was ringing I heard that last caller and I just want to tell her to hang in there.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_smiles at Roz_] That's very kind of you. [_presses another button_] Go ahead, caller.  I'm listening.

speaker: Carl
text: [_v.o._] Hi, uh, my name's Carl.

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, Carl.

speaker: Carl
text: I'm kind of going through the same thing as that Roberta woman.

speaker: Frasier
text: Really?  Well, then perhaps you could share your experience with us and possibly help Roberta and some of our other listeners.

speaker: Carl
text: Well, it's hard to talk about.  She hasn't technically dumped me yet, but I'm pretty sure it's coming.  And I don't know if I should bring it up first, or just avoid the whole subject and hope things get better.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, Carl, uh...  these problems rarely resolve themselves. I realize that an honest conversation at this point may be a little daunting, but...  _As he goes on, we FADE TO:  Scene Six - Apartment Daphne is sanding the finished TV table._

speaker: Daphne
text: I'm finished!  It turned out great.

speaker: Daphne
text: I'm sorry I yelled at you.  You were a big help.  I couldn't have done it without you.

speaker: Martin
text: You mean it?

speaker: Daphne
text: Absolutely.  Come and take a look.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, that is sharp!  Niles, come look at the table.  _Daphne looks guilty again as Niles slowly follows Martin out of the powder room.   His eyes are red-rimmed._

speaker: Niles
text: [_sulky_] I like the footpads.
